qas.question: What specifies the amino acid sequence of a protein?

answers.text: The nucleotide sequence of a gene's DNA

qas.question: What are sets of three nucleotides known as?
What does each codon correspond to?
What indicates the beginning and end of the protein coding region?
How many possible codons are there?

answers.text: There are 64 possible codons (four possible nucleotides at each of three positions, hence 43 possible codons)

context: <a0_0>The nucleotide sequence of a gene's DNA<a0_0/> specifies the amino acid sequence of a protein through the genetic code. Sets of three nucleotides, known as <a1_0>codons<a1_0/>, each correspond to <a2_0>a specific amino acid<a2_0/>.:6 Additionally, <a3_0>a "start codon", and three "stop codons"<a3_0/> indicate the beginning and end of the protein coding region. <a4_0>There are 64 possible codons (four possible nucleotides at each of three positions, hence 43 possible codons)<a4_0/> and only 20 standard amino acids; hence the code is redundant and multiple codons can specify the same amino acid. The correspondence between codons and amino acids is nearly universal among all known living organisms.
